bibl.title: [Claim] 1820 July 27, State of Tennessee, to the Sheriff of Rhea County
bibl.note: This document, dated July 27, 1820, is a legal claim concerning a legal suit brought against Joseph Tompson by William Cochrine. Tompson was sued by Cochrine over money he owed to Cochrine in the amount of 250.00.

address.addrLine: State of Tennessee To the sheriff of Rhea County

div.p: Greetings. We command you to take William Cochrine if to be found in your county and him safly safely keep so as to hear him at the next court of pleas and quarter sessions to be held for the county of Rhea and in the town of Washington at the courthouse on the first Monday of August next to answer Joseph Tompson of a plea of Trespas Trespass on the case to his damages five hundred Dollars and have you then there this Writ ――― Witness Daniel Rollings
Clerk of said county court at office in Washington the first monday of may 1820 & 44 year of our Independence ― D. Rollings, Clerk

Know all men by this presents that we Joseph Tompson and James Prentice are Bound to William Cochrine in the sum of $250. to be paid of the said Joseph Tompson shall with effect prosecute a suit by him this day commenced against the said William Cochrine or in case of falure failure pay all costs of this suit Witness our hands and seals the 27th of July 1820. Joseph Thompson hand drawn seal James Prentice hand drawn seal

on the back of the above
casses cases & bond The Endorsement, follows was as follows

Case & respondent Joseph Thompson vs William Cochrine signed 27 July 1820 Came to hand the same day signed
Wm William Francis Sheriff not to be found in my county Wm Francis

State of Tennessee Rhea County }
February session 1821 Joseph Tompson by his atorney attorney
comp complains of William Cocrine in the custody of the sheriff of a plea of trespass on the case for that where as the said Joseph Tompson now is a good true honest great and faithful citesin citizen and as such hath allways likeined and shall continue to behave conducted himself and untill until the commiting committing of the said grievances by the said William Cocrine as hereinafter mentioned was always respected esteemed and acredited by and among his all his neighbours and other good and worth citizens to whom he was in any way known to be a person of good name fame and credit at to wit in the county afforesaid aforesaid and whereas also the said Joseph Thompson hath not ever been guilty as untill until the time of the commiting of the of the said several grievances by the said William Cochrine as hereinafter mentioned been suspected to have been guilty of larciny larceny or any other such crimes by means of which said premises he the said Joseph Tompson before the commiting of the said grevances grievances by the William Cochrine as hereinafter mentioned had universaly universally obtained the good opinion and credit of all his neighbours and other good and worthy citizens to whom he was in any way known at to wit in the county aforesaid Yet the said William well knowing the premises but greatly injuring the happy state and condition of the said Joseph and contriving and wickedly and maliciously intending to injure the said Joseph in his said good name fame and credit and to bring him into public scandal infamy and disgrace with and among all his neighbours and other good and worthy citizens and to cause it to be suspected and believed by more neighbours and citizens that he the said Joseph had been guilty and was guilty of larceny
and to subject him to the pains and penalties by the laws of the land made and provided against and inflicted upon persons guilty thereof and to harrass oppress impoverish and wholly ruin him the said Joseph heretofore to wit on this day and year last afforesaid at to wit in the county afforesaid lately wickedly maliciously in a certain conversation then and there held by and between him the said William and a certain--- and in the presence and hereing of diverse other good and worthy citizens did speak and publish of and concerning the said Joseph these falce false and slanderous words following that is to say" he (meaning the said Joseph) has stolen corn and I can prove it" By means of the commity of the said greavances by the said William as afforesaid he the said Joseph hath been and is greatly injured in his said good name fame and credit and brought into public scandal infamy and disgrace with and among all his neighbours and other good and worthy citizens insomuch that divers diverse of those neighbours and citizens to whom the inocence innocence and integrity of the said Joseph in the premises were unknown have on ocassion of the committing of the said greviances grievances by the said William as aforesaid from thence hitherto suspected and believed and still do suspect and believe the said Joseph to have been and to be a person guilty of larceny and have by reason of the commiting of the said greivances by the said William as aforesaid from these hitherto wholly refused and still do refuse to have any thing to do with transactions acquaintance or discourse with him the said Joseph as they were before used and sustained to have and otherwise would whereof the said Joseph saith that he is injured and hath sustained damages five hundred dollars and therefore the suit &c

S Spencer Jarnagan

div.p:
Joseph Thompson
vs versus
William Cochrine
{Stander The defendent by atorney attorney comes and defends the wrong and injury & have &c and plea sais saith the plaintiff his actions action thereof against him ought not to have and mantain maintain because he sais he is not guilty in manner and form as the plaintiff against him hath alledged alleged of this he puts him self upon the County
div.closer:
Mitchele atto. for deft defendant
and the plaintiff doth the like
Jarnaganatto. And for further plea in this behalf the said defendant says the plaintiff his action against him ought not to have and mantain Because he says the said plaintiff before the speaking and publishing words supposed to have been spoken and published by the said defendant of and concerning the said plaintiff (Yes) the day and year in the plaintiff declaration mentioned did steal and take corn and therefore the said plaintiff is as bad a man as he represented him to be all which he is ready to verify Wherefore he pays Judgement &c and et cetera
Michel atto. for Deft.
Replication & Speus Jarnagan and Mitchel atto.
